section.title: Defining a target platform
section.para: You can specify your target platform with a target definition file . With such a file you define the available plug-ins and features.

tip.para: A target platform can be defined based on software sites (p2 update sites) or other means. As build systems like Maven Tycho support only p2 update sites, it is recommended to use only these.

section.para:
A target definition file can be created via
File New Other... Plug-in Development Target Definition
.

textobject.phrase: Define File name for Target Definition

section.para: You can add new locations via the Add... button in the Locations section. To add an Eclipse p2 update site, select Software Site and specify the URL.

Once you have a target definition file, you can set it as the target platform in your Eclipse IDE. This can be done via the Set as Target Platform link in the Target definition editor as depicted in the following screenshot.

textobject.phrase: Setting the new defined target definition as target for the development

tip.para: Wait until the target platform is completely resolved before setting it as target platform.

section.para: All plug-ins you are planning to use in your application and test code must be included in the target definition. For example, if you want, for example, use SWTBot for unit tests, add SWTBot for SWT Testing features from http://download.eclipse.org/technology/swtbot/releases/latest/ to your target platform.

textobject.phrase: Definition of a target definition file

section.para:
You can switch the target platform in the Eclipse Preferences. Select
Window Preferences Plug-in Development Target Platform
.

textobject.phrase: Setting the target definition via the Eclipse Preferences

section.para: The most effective way of defining your target platform is to use p2 update sites. These are of the same type as the update sites that you used to install a new set of plug-ins. If the content in the update sites defined by your target platform changes, your local set of plug-ins can be updated.

It is also possible to define your target platform based on plug-ins in your file system, but this is not recommended as certain build system like Maven/Tycho do not support file based target definition files.
